Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Windows of Opportunity: Exploring the Controls on the Depths of Eruption-forming Silicic Magma Bodies Using Improved Thermodynamics and Dynamics Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
A growing number of lines of evidence suggest that silicic magma bodies ? which give rise to hazardous explosive volcanic eruptions ? are characteristic and possibly restricted to shallow levels of the Earthh's crust. Why is this the case? What controls the depths from which eruptions emanate? Is it possible to generate and erupt silicic magma from deeper levels within the crust? How do magma properties, such as density and viscosity, interact with crustal properties, such as rigidity and elasticity, to ultimately control the eruption of magmas? These questions underlie the scientific motivation for this project that will address them by developing theoretical models derived from physical and chemical theory in order to predict the behavior of crustal magmas at the onset of volcanic eruption.

In this project, the collaborative team will build upon their ongoing effort to develop coupled thermodynamics and fluid dynamics models, and to apply these models to selected natural systems. In their previous work, they developed an improved model to perform thermodynamic calculations of phase relations for silicic magmas and laid the foundation for coupling thermodynamics and fluid dynamics models by applying them to several natural systems. With this with this Accomplishment-based renewal award, they will expand these thermodynamic models to include the effects of carbon dioxide and sulfur on the fluid phase, and fully couple them with new and existing fluid dynamics models of both magmas and country-rocks, permitting rigorous evaluation of the interplay between phase change, magma dynamics, and country-rock behavior. It is also planned used the coupled models to several silicic systems including the Bishop Tuff, Peach Spring Tuff, Oruanui Tuff and Cotopaxi Volcano.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Observations of current volcanoes and analysis of the geological record reveal that large volumes of silica-rich magmas can accumulate and form bodies of magma within the subsurface of the Earth. Some fraction of these magmas crystallize at depth within the Earth’s crust to form granites. But some fraction of these magmas erupt to the surface, and they do so in a variety of ways, both effusively and explosively. Several important questions arise: Why do some silicic magmas erupt while others stall in the subsurface? Why do some magmas erupt effusively while others do so explosively? Are these different magmas that are predestined to different eruptive potential and style, or are they similar magmas subject to different contingencies?

Much attention in the petrologic literature has been given to the importance of external triggers in initiating eruptions, for instance, by injection of new magma or by the action of earthquakes. Many lines of evidence suggest, however, that self-conditioning of magma bodies is important in determining their fate. During magma solidification, the combined effect of crystallization (formation of solids) and volatile exsolution (formation of bubbles) can lead to increases in magma volume, which, in turn, can pressurize the magma body against the surrounding rock. If such pressurization is large enough, it is possible that the magma body evolution can lead to eruption without external triggers. This project aimed to investigate the role of this self-conditioning – priming – process in triggering eruptions. We used thermodynamic calculations using the computational program rhyolite-MELTS to better understand these processes. We found that eruptions of silicic magmas, which are typically explosive in nature, can be triggered internally due to the magma expansion resulting from bubble exsolution. Because bubble density is a function of pressure (higher pressure, higher density), shallower magma bodies are more easily erupted than deeper magma bodies. In fact, we found that there is a window within the Earth’s crust from which eruptions can be triggered internally – within the first 11 km of the Earth’s crust, eruptions are easily triggered, suggesting that is the region from which most crustal magmas erupt. Our calculations reveal a minimum crystal proportion necessary to lead to internal triggering – the fact that these calculated crystallinities are similar to those observed in natural rocks indicates that internal triggering is an important process in driving eruptions. In fact, our results suggest that internal conditioning is a critical process, which leads magma bodies to a state in which eruption is likely or inevitable, with external triggers representing only the final blow, rather than the driving force that drives eruption.

Prior studies, as well as work performed as part of this project, emphasize the importance of volatiles in the evolution and eruption of magmas. Another important aim of this project was to create thermodynamic models that better describe the role and evolution of volatiles in silicic magmas. We developed a model for mixed H2O-CO2 fluids (as opposed to the pure H2O model available) in equilibrium with silicate melts. This model is coupled with rhyolite-MELTS and thus allows more realistic calculations of the evolution of magmas, now considering the two most abundant volatile species in magmas – H2O and CO2. The model is available free of charge from http://melts.ofm-research.org.
